coredata.dc:title: Interactions between electro-neutral surfaces bearing mobile charges
coredata.dc:creator: Attard, Phil
Kjellander, Roland
Mitchell, D.John
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
We investigate electrically neutral surfaces composed of mobile charged particles. For a single surface the long-range tail of the charge correlations is independent of the details of the system. The pressure between two such surfaces at large separations, h, is universal (depending only on temperature), always attractive, and decays like h −3. The asymptotic law for the total pressure is independent of the magnitude of the dielectric discontinuities at the surfaces. Unless the zero-frequency dispersion interaction of the dielectric media is included, the pressure will contain an artificial repulsive contribution due to the image charge interactions.

John MITCHELL Department of Applied Mathematics, Research School of Physical Sciences, Australian National University, Canberrra, A.C.T. 2601, Australia Received 9 April 1987; in final form 29 May 1987 We investigate electrically neutral surfaces composed of mobile charged particles. For a single surface the long-range tail of the charge correlations is independent of the details of the system. The pressure between two such surfaces at large separations, h, is universal (depending only on temperature), always attractive, and decays like h~3. The asymptotic law for the total pressure is independent of the magnitude of the dielectric discontinuities at the surfaces. Unless the zero-frequency dispersion interaction of the dielectric media is included, the pressure will contain an artificial repulsive contribution due to the image charge interactions. 1. Introduction We present here an analysis of the interactions between surfaces bearing laterally mobile charges but which are overall electrically neutral. The short-range interactions between the charged particles are arbitrary. There is no added electrolyte in this system and the intervening medium is described solely by its dielectric constant. The point is this: A full understanding of the primitive model is essential to decide, whether continuum elec- trostatics alone can account for the forces between surfaces with adsorbed charges, or, if some extra "hydration forces" are involved. The systems studied are relevant to the interpretation of the measured forces between charged surfaces completely neutralised by adsorbed ions (or surfactants) provided they retain a degree of mobility along the surface. Also, lamellar phases formed from equimolar mixtures ofcationic and anionic sur- factants should exhibit the forces we describe here. The mean field perturbation theory we develop is based on a perturbation expansion to all orders. For some systems (e.g. Coulomb or dipolar bulk fluids), each term in the usual expansion gives contributions of the same order in the expansion parameter (e.g. separation). Hence it would be incorrect to truncate the expansion after some finite number of terms. In the more sophisticated analysis we apply here all leading contributions are retained. Previously [ 1 ] two of us have used first- and second-order perturbation theory to find the forces between surfaces composed of dipolar particles. Then we did not need the full mean field perturbation theory as we do for the present problem with ionic layers at the surfaces. Whilst we illustrate the theory by this par- ticular problem, we note that it is generally applicable to fluids with long-range potentials. 2. Long-range correlations have been found in inhomogeneous electrolytes parallel to a planar surface [3,4] although the universal nature of our result appears unique to the present problem. It is the ana- logue of the Stillinger-Lovett second-moment condition for bulk electrolytes [5]. To obtain the total pressure in a consistent treatment of his primitive model, one must add the attractive zero-frequency dispersion interaction of the die- lectric media, given by the Lifshitz theory [6]. This contribution cancels the second term in (21) identically. Hence, even in the presence of images, the total pressure between the surfaces at large separations is given by the universal result (17)! Physically, one can understand that the long-range interaction between conducting layers should be independent of any dielectric discontinuities behind them. We can conclude that it is important to treat the system in a consistent manner and consider all effects of the dielectric discontinuities. Unless the zero-frequency dispersion interaction is added, the pressure will con- tain an artificial repulsive contribution. Note that the dielectric properties of real systems at non-zero fre- 223 Volume 139, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 21 August 1987 quencies are not included in the model. However, to a good approximation the corresponding dispersion interaction can be added to the pressure obtained above since the ion distributions do not respond much to high-frequency fields. Again the asymptotic pressure law is a general result that, for instance, is fulfilled in the Debye-Hiickel approximation. The pair distribution ff?" is obtained from (11) using s from (18) and T^". Thence the Debye-Hiickel free energy (and pressure) is obtained from (19), and to leading order it reduces to (17) when the zero-frequency dispersion interaction is added. The total pressure is, in fact, independent of the images until the term in h ~5. Previous Debye-Hiickel analysis [9] predicted a faster asymptotic decay than the cubic we find here because the pressure was then erroneously taken to be the derivative of the internal energy rather than the free energy. The universal contribution (17) is entirely entropic. Fig. 1 shows the attractive pressure both with and without the zero-frequency dispersion contribution. In the absence of dielectric discontinuities, the latter is, of course, equal to zero. It can be seen that the Debye-Hiickel results, for a mixture of anions and cations at 75 A2 per particle pair, lie close to the universal results. The pressure predicted is comparable to the conventional van der Waals force for e.g. hydrocarbon or mica across water. The universal asymptotic result is always more attractive than the Debye-Hiickel pressure. However, one can show that the universal law does not provide an upper bound on the exact attractive interaction, since fo(0) may be negative for highly coupled systems [8]. We have derived a mean field perturbation theory, which is applicable to fluids with long-range potentials, and it was used to describe the interactions between neutral surfaces bearing mobile charges. We will show in a future publication that the results agree surprisingly well with more accurate numerical calculations [ 8 ]. We are presently extending this work to include an electrolyte between the neutral surfaces and are also examining the electric double layer near a charged surface.
